inlineOnly.description:
Bundle only the dependencies listed here; throw an error if any others are missing.

Note: Be sure to include all required sub-dependencies as well.
inlineOnly.markdownDescription:
Bundle only the dependencies listed here; throw an error if any others are missing.

Note: Be sure to include all required sub-dependencies as well.

platform.description:
Specifies the target runtime platform for the build.

- `node`: Node.js and compatible runtimes (e.g., Deno, Bun).   For CJS format, this is always set to `node` and cannot be changed.
- `neutral`: A platform-agnostic target with no specific runtime assumptions.
- `browser`: Web browsers.
platform.markdownDescription:
Specifies the target runtime platform for the build.

- `node`: Node.js and compatible runtimes (e.g., Deno, Bun).
  For CJS format, this is always set to `node` and cannot be changed.
- `neutral`: A platform-agnostic target with no specific runtime assumptions.
- `browser`: Web browsers.

target.description:
Specifies the compilation target environment(s).

Determines the JavaScript version or runtime(s) for which the code should be compiled. If not set, defaults to the value of `engines.node` in your project's `package.json`. If no `engines.node` field exists, no syntax transformations are applied.

Accepts a single target (e.g., `'es2020'`, `'node18'`), an array of targets, or `false` to disable all transformations.
target.markdownDescription:
Specifies the compilation target environment(s).

Determines the JavaScript version or runtime(s) for which the code should be compiled.
If not set, defaults to the value of `engines.node` in your project's `package.json`.
If no `engines.node` field exists, no syntax transformations are applied.

Accepts a single target (e.g., `'es2020'`, `'node18'`), an array of targets, or `false` to disable all transformations.

env.description: Compile-time env variables, which can be accessed via `import.meta.env` or `process.env`.
env.markdownDescription: Compile-time env variables, which can be accessed via `import.meta.env` or `process.env`.

envFile.description: Path to env file providing compile-time env variables.
envFile.markdownDescription: Path to env file providing compile-time env variables.

envPrefix.description: When loading env variables from `envFile`, only include variables with these prefixes.
envPrefix.markdownDescription: When loading env variables from `envFile`, only include variables with these prefixes.

moduleSideEffects.description:
**Values:**

- **`true`**: All modules are assumed to have side effects and will be included in the bundle even if none of their exports are used.
- **`false`**: No modules have side effects. This enables aggressive tree-shaking, removing any modules whose exports are not used.
- **`string[]`**: Array of module IDs that have side effects. Only modules in this list will be preserved if unused; all others can be tree-shaken when their exports are unused.
- **`'no-external'`**: Assumes no external modules have side effects while preserving the default behavior for local modules.
- **`ModuleSideEffectsRule[]`**: Array of rules with `test`, `external`, and `sideEffects` properties for fine-grained control.
- **`function`**: Function that receives `(id, external)` and returns whether the module has side effects.

**Important:** Setting this to `false` or using an array/string assumes that your modules and their dependencies have no side effects other than their exports. Only use this if you're certain that removing unused modules won't break your application.

> [!NOTE] > **Performance: Prefer `ModuleSideEffectsRule[]` over functions** > > When possible, use rule-based configuration instead of functions. Rules are processed entirely in Rust, while JavaScript functions require runtime calls between Rust and JavaScript, which can hurt CPU utilization during builds. > > **Functions should be a last resort**: Only use the function signature when your logic cannot be expressed with patterns or simple string matching. > > **Rule advantages**: `ModuleSideEffectsRule[]` provides better performance by avoiding Rust-JavaScript runtime calls, clearer intent, and easier maintenance.
moduleSideEffects.markdownDescription:
**Values:**

- **`true`**: All modules are assumed to have side effects and will be included in the bundle even if none of their exports are used.
- **`false`**: No modules have side effects. This enables aggressive tree-shaking, removing any modules whose exports are not used.
- **`string[]`**: Array of module IDs that have side effects. Only modules in this list will be preserved if unused; all others can be tree-shaken when their exports are unused.
- **`'no-external'`**: Assumes no external modules have side effects while preserving the default behavior for local modules.
- **`ModuleSideEffectsRule[]`**: Array of rules with `test`, `external`, and `sideEffects` properties for fine-grained control.
- **`function`**: Function that receives `(id, external)` and returns whether the module has side effects.

**Important:** Setting this to `false` or using an array/string assumes that your modules and their dependencies have no side effects other than their exports. Only use this if you're certain that removing unused modules won't break your application.

> [!NOTE]
> **Performance: Prefer `ModuleSideEffectsRule[]` over functions**
>
> When possible, use rule-based configuration instead of functions. Rules are processed entirely in Rust, while JavaScript functions require runtime calls between Rust and JavaScript, which can hurt CPU utilization during builds.
>
> **Functions should be a last resort**: Only use the function signature when your logic cannot be expressed with patterns or simple string matching.
>
> **Rule advantages**: `ModuleSideEffectsRule[]` provides better performance by avoiding Rust-JavaScript runtime calls, clearer intent, and easier maintenance.

annotations.description:
Whether to respect `/*@__PURE__*\/` annotations and other tree-shaking hints in the code.

See [related Oxc documentation](https://oxc.rs/docs/guide/usage/minifier/dead-code-elimination#pure-annotations) for more details.
annotations.markdownDescription:
Whether to respect `/*@__PURE__*\/` annotations and other tree-shaking hints in the code.

See [related Oxc documentation](https://oxc.rs/docs/guide/usage/minifier/dead-code-elimination#pure-annotations) for more details.

manualPureFunctions.description:
Array of function names that should be considered pure (no side effects) even if they can't be automatically detected as pure.

See [related Oxc documentation](https://oxc.rs/docs/guide/usage/minifier/dead-code-elimination#define-pure-functions) for more details.
manualPureFunctions.markdownDescription:
Array of function names that should be considered pure (no side effects) even if they can't be automatically detected as pure.

See [related Oxc documentation](https://oxc.rs/docs/guide/usage/minifier/dead-code-elimination#define-pure-functions) for more details.

unknownGlobalSideEffects.description:
Whether to assume that accessing unknown global properties might have side effects.

See [related Oxc documentation](https://oxc.rs/docs/guide/usage/minifier/dead-code-elimination#ignoring-global-variable-access-side-effects) for more details.
unknownGlobalSideEffects.markdownDescription:
Whether to assume that accessing unknown global properties might have side effects.

See [related Oxc documentation](https://oxc.rs/docs/guide/usage/minifier/dead-code-elimination#ignoring-global-variable-access-side-effects) for more details.

commonjs.description:
Whether to enable tree-shaking for CommonJS modules. When `true`, unused exports from CommonJS modules can be eliminated from the bundle, similar to ES modules. When disabled, CommonJS modules will always be included in their entirety.

This option allows rolldown to analyze `exports.property` assignments in CommonJS modules and remove unused exports while preserving the module's side effects.
commonjs.markdownDescription:
Whether to enable tree-shaking for CommonJS modules. When `true`, unused exports from CommonJS modules can be eliminated from the bundle, similar to ES modules. When disabled, CommonJS modules will always be included in their entirety.

This option allows rolldown to analyze `exports.property` assignments in CommonJS modules and remove unused exports while preserving the module's side effects.

propertyReadSideEffects.description:
Controls whether reading properties from objects is considered to have side effects.

Set to `false` for more aggressive tree-shaking behavior.

See [related Oxc documentation](https://oxc.rs/docs/guide/usage/minifier/dead-code-elimination#ignoring-property-read-side-effects) for more details.
propertyReadSideEffects.markdownDescription:
Controls whether reading properties from objects is considered to have side effects.

propertyWriteSideEffects.description:
Controls whether writing properties to objects is considered to have side effects.

Set to `false` for more aggressive behavior.
propertyWriteSideEffects.markdownDescription:

anyOf.markdownDescription: When passing an object, you can fine-tune the tree-shaking behavior.

loader.description: Sets how input files are processed. For example, use 'js' to treat files as JavaScript or 'base64' for images. Lets you import or require files like images or fonts.

removeNodeProtocol.description: If enabled, strips the `node:` protocol prefix from import source.
removeNodeProtocol.markdownDescription: If enabled, strips the `node:` protocol prefix from import source.

nodeProtocol.description:
- If `true`, add `node:` prefix to built-in modules.
- If `'strip'`, strips the `node:` protocol prefix from import source.
- If `false`, does not modify the import source.
nodeProtocol.markdownDescription:
- If `true`, add `node:` prefix to built-in modules.

circularDependency.description:
Whether to emit warnings when detecting circular dependency

Circular dependencies lead to a bigger bundle size and sometimes cause execution order issues and are better to avoid.
circularDependency.markdownDescription:

unresolvedEntry.markdownDescription: Whether to emit warnings when an entrypoint cannot be resolved

unresolvedImport.description: Whether to emit warnings when an import cannot be resolved
unresolvedImport.markdownDescription: Whether to emit warnings when an import cannot be resolved

filenameConflict.description: Whether to emit warnings when files generated have the same name with different contents
filenameConflict.markdownDescription: Whether to emit warnings when files generated have the same name with different contents

commonJsVariableInEsm.description:
Whether to emit warnings when a CommonJS variable is used in an ES module

CommonJS variables like `module` and `exports` are treated as global variables in ES modules and may not work as expected.
commonJsVariableInEsm.markdownDescription:
Whether to emit warnings when a CommonJS variable is used in an ES module

importIsUndefined.description:
Whether to emit warnings when an imported variable is not exported

If the code is importing a variable that is not exported by the imported module, the value will always be `undefined`. This might be a mistake in the code.
importIsUndefined.markdownDescription:
Whether to emit warnings when an imported variable is not exported

If the code is importing a variable that is not exported by the imported module, the value will always be `undefined`. This might be a mistake in the code.

emptyImportMeta.description:

See [`import.meta` in Non-ESM Output Formats page](https://rolldown.rs/in-depth/non-esm-output-formats#import-meta) for more details.

toleratedTransform.markdownDescription: Whether to emit warnings when detecting tolerated transform

cannotCallNamespace.description:
Whether to emit warnings when a namespace is called as a function

A module namespace object is an object and not a function. Calling it as a function will cause a runtime error.

preferBuiltinFeature.description:

Using built-in features is generally more performant than using plugins.

enforce.markdownDescription: Vite-specific option to control plugin ordering

plugins.description:
The list of plugins to use.

Falsy plugins will be ignored, which can be used to easily activate or deactivate plugins. Nested plugins will be flattened. Async plugins will be awaited and resolved.

alias.description:
Substitute one package for another.

One use case for this feature is replacing a node-only package with a browser-friendly package in third-party code that you don't control.
alias.markdownDescription:
Substitute one package for another.

One use case for this feature is replacing a node-only package with a browser-friendly package in third-party code that you don't control.

aliasFields.description:
Fields in package.json to check for aliased paths.

This option is expected to be used for `browser` field support.
aliasFields.markdownDescription:
Fields in package.json to check for aliased paths.

This option is expected to be used for `browser` field support.

conditionNames.description: Condition names to use when resolving exports in package.json.
conditionNames.markdownDescription: Condition names to use when resolving exports in package.json.
conditionNames.default:
Defaults based on platform and import kind:
- `browser` platform
  - `["import", "browser", "default"]` for import statements
  - `["require", "browser", "default"]` for require() calls
- `node` platform
  - `["import", "node", "default"]` for import statements
  - `["require", "node", "default"]` for require() calls
- `neutral` platform
  - `["import", "default"]` for import statements
  - `["require", "default"]` for require() calls

extensionAlias.description:
Map of extensions to alternative extensions.

With writing `import './foo.js'` in a file, you want to resolve it to `foo.ts` instead of `foo.js`. You can achieve this by setting: `extensionAlias: { '.js': ['.ts', '.js'] }`.
extensionAlias.markdownDescription:
Map of extensions to alternative extensions.

With writing `import './foo.js'` in a file, you want to resolve it to `foo.ts` instead of `foo.js`.
You can achieve this by setting: `extensionAlias: { '.js': ['.ts', '.js'] }`.

exportsFields.description: Fields in package.json to check for exports.
exportsFields.markdownDescription: Fields in package.json to check for exports.

extensions.description: Extensions to try when resolving files. These are tried in order from first to last.
extensions.markdownDescription: Extensions to try when resolving files. These are tried in order from first to last.

mainFields.description: Fields in package.json to check for entry points.
mainFields.markdownDescription: Fields in package.json to check for entry points.
mainFields.default:
Defaults based on platform:
- `node` platform: `['main', 'module']`
- `browser` platform: `['browser', 'module', 'main']`
- `neutral` platform: `[]`

mainFiles.description: Filenames to try when resolving directories.
mainFiles.markdownDescription: Filenames to try when resolving directories.

symlinks.description: Whether to follow symlinks when resolving modules.
symlinks.markdownDescription: Whether to follow symlinks when resolving modules.

resolve.description: Options for built-in module resolution feature.
resolve.markdownDescription: Options for built-in module resolution feature.

cwd.description: The working directory to use when resolving relative paths in the configuration.
cwd.markdownDescription: The working directory to use when resolving relative paths in the configuration.

platform.description:
Expected platform where the code run.

 When the platform is set to neutral:    - When bundling is enabled the default output format is set to esm, which uses the export syntax introduced with ECMAScript 2015 (i.e. ES6). You can change the output format if this default is not appropriate.    - The main fields setting is empty by default. If you want to use npm-style packages, you will likely have to configure this to be something else such as main for the standard main field used by node.    - The conditions setting does not automatically include any platform-specific values.
platform.markdownDescription:
Expected platform where the code run.

 When the platform is set to neutral:
   - When bundling is enabled the default output format is set to esm, which uses the export syntax introduced with ECMAScript 2015 (i.e. ES6). You can change the output format if this default is not appropriate.
   - The main fields setting is empty by default. If you want to use npm-style packages, you will likely have to configure this to be something else such as main for the standard main field used by node.
   - The conditions setting does not automatically include any platform-specific values.

moduleSideEffects.description:
**Values:**

- **`true`**: All modules are assumed to have side effects and will be included in the bundle even if none of their exports are used.
- **`false`**: No modules have side effects. This enables aggressive tree-shaking, removing any modules whose exports are not used.
- **`string[]`**: Array of module IDs that have side effects. Only modules in this list will be preserved if unused; all others can be tree-shaken when their exports are unused.
- **`'no-external'`**: Assumes no external modules have side effects while preserving the default behavior for local modules.
- **`ModuleSideEffectsRule[]`**: Array of rules with `test`, `external`, and `sideEffects` properties for fine-grained control.
- **`function`**: Function that receives `(id, external)` and returns whether the module has side effects.

**Important:** Setting this to `false` or using an array/string assumes that your modules and their dependencies have no side effects other than their exports. Only use this if you're certain that removing unused modules won't break your application.

> [!NOTE] > **Performance: Prefer `ModuleSideEffectsRule[]` over functions** > > When possible, use rule-based configuration instead of functions. logLevel.description:
Controls the verbosity of console logging during the build.

{@include ./docs/log-level.md}

moduleTypes.description:
Maps file patterns to module types, controlling how files are processed.

This is conceptually similar to esbuild's loader option, allowing you to specify how different file extensions should be handled.
moduleTypes.markdownDescription:
Maps file patterns to module types, controlling how files are processed.

This is conceptually similar to esbuild's loader option, allowing you to specify how different file extensions should be handled.

strictExecutionOrder.description:
Lets modules be executed in the order they are declared.

This is done by injecting runtime helpers to ensure that modules are executed in the order they are imported. External modules won't be affected.

> [!WARNING] > Enabling this option may negatively increase bundle size. It is recommended to use this option only when absolutely necessary.
strictExecutionOrder.markdownDescription:
Lets modules be executed in the order they are declared.

This is done by injecting runtime helpers to ensure that modules are executed in the order they are imported. External modules won't be affected.

> [!WARNING]
> Enabling this option may negatively increase bundle size. It is recommended to use this option only when absolutely necessary.

resolveNewUrlToAsset.description:
When enabled, `new URL()` calls will be transformed to a stable asset URL which includes the updated name and content hash. It is necessary to pass `import.meta.url` as the second argument to the `new URL` constructor, otherwise no transform will be applied. :::warning JavaScript and TypeScript files referenced via `new URL('./file.js', import.meta.url)` or `new URL('./file.ts', import.meta.url)` will **not** be transformed or bundled. The file will be copied as-is, meaning TypeScript files remain untransformed and dependencies are not resolved.

The expected behavior for JS/TS files is still being discussed and may change in future releases. See [#7258](https://github.com/rolldown/rolldown/issues/7258) for more context. :::
resolveNewUrlToAsset.markdownDescription:
When enabled, `new URL()` calls will be transformed to a stable asset URL which includes the updated name and content hash.
It is necessary to pass `import.meta.url` as the second argument to the
`new URL` constructor, otherwise no transform will be applied.
:::warning
JavaScript and TypeScript files referenced via `new URL('./file.js', import.meta.url)` or `new URL('./file.ts', import.meta.url)` will **not** be transformed or bundled. The file will be copied as-is, meaning TypeScript files remain untransformed and dependencies are not resolved.

The expected behavior for JS/TS files is still being discussed and may
change in future releases. See [#7258](https://github.com/rolldown/rolldown/issues/7258) for more context.
:::

chunkModulesOrder.description:
Control which order should be used when rendering modules in a chunk.

Available options:
- `exec-order`: Almost equivalent to the topological order of the module graph, but specially handling when module graph has cycle.
- `module-id`: This is more friendly for gzip compression, especially for some javascript static asset lib (e.g. icon library)

> [!NOTE] > Try to sort the modules by their module id if possible (Since rolldown scope hoist all modules in the chunk, we only try to sort those modules by module id if we could ensure runtime behavior is correct after sorting).
chunkModulesOrder.markdownDescription:
Control which order should be used when rendering modules in a chunk.

Available options:
- `exec-order`: Almost equivalent to the topological order of the module graph, but specially handling when module graph has cycle.
- `module-id`: This is more friendly for gzip compression, especially for some javascript static asset lib (e.g. icon library)

> [!NOTE]
> Try to sort the modules by their module id if possible (Since rolldown scope hoist all modules in the chunk, we only try to sort those modules by module id if we could ensure runtime behavior is correct after sorting).

attachDebugInfo.description:
Attach debug information to the output bundle.

Available modes:
- `none`: No debug information is attached.
- `simple`: Attach comments indicating which files the bundled code comes from. These comments could be removed by the minifier.
- `full`: Attach detailed debug information to the output bundle. These comments are using legal comment syntax, so they won't be removed by the minifier.
attachDebugInfo.markdownDescription:
Attach debug information to the output bundle.

Available modes:
- `none`: No debug information is attached.
- `simple`: Attach comments indicating which files the bundled code comes from. These comments could be removed by the minifier.
- `full`: Attach detailed debug information to the output bundle. These comments are using legal comment syntax, so they won't be removed by the minifier.

chunkImportMap.description:
Enables automatic generation of a chunk import map asset during build.

This map only includes chunks with hashed filenames, where keys are derived from the facade module name or primary chunk name. It produces stable and unique hash-based filenames, effectively preventing cascading cache invalidation caused by content hashes and maximizing browser cache reuse.

The output defaults to `importmap.json` unless overridden via `fileName`. A base URL prefix (default `"/"`) can be applied to all paths. The resulting JSON is a valid import map and can be directly injected into HTML via `<script type="importmap">`.
chunkImportMap.markdownDescription:
Enables automatic generation of a chunk import map asset during build.

This map only includes chunks with hashed filenames, where keys are derived from the facade module
name or primary chunk name. It produces stable and unique hash-based filenames, effectively preventing
cascading cache invalidation caused by content hashes and maximizing browser cache reuse.

The output defaults to `importmap.json` unless overridden via `fileName`. A base URL prefix
(default `"/"`) can be applied to all paths. The resulting JSON is a valid import map and can be
directly injected into HTML via `<script type="importmap">`.

incrementalBuild.description: Enable incremental build support. Required to be used with `watch` mode.
incrementalBuild.markdownDescription: Enable incremental build support. Required to be used with `watch` mode.

transformHiresSourcemap.description: Enable high-resolution source maps for transform operations.
transformHiresSourcemap.markdownDescription: Enable high-resolution source maps for transform operations.

nativeMagicString.description:
Use native Rust implementation of MagicString for source map generation.

[MagicString](https://github.com/rich-harris/magic-string) is a JavaScript library commonly used by bundlers for string manipulation and source map generation. When enabled, rolldown will use a native Rust implementation of MagicString instead of the JavaScript version, providing significantly better performance during source map generation and code transformation.

**Benefits**

- **Improved Performance**: The native Rust implementation is typically faster than the JavaScript version,   especially for large codebases with extensive source maps.
- **Background Processing**: Source map generation is performed asynchronously in a background thread,   allowing the main bundling process to continue without blocking. This parallel processing can significantly   reduce overall build times when working with JavaScript transform hooks.
- **Better Integration**: Seamless integration with rolldown's native Rust architecture.
nativeMagicString.markdownDescription:
Use native Rust implementation of MagicString for source map generation.

[MagicString](https://github.com/rich-harris/magic-string) is a JavaScript library commonly used by bundlers
for string manipulation and source map generation. When enabled, rolldown will use a native Rust
implementation of MagicString instead of the JavaScript version, providing significantly better performance
during source map generation and code transformation.

**Benefits**

- **Improved Performance**: The native Rust implementation is typically faster than the JavaScript version,
  especially for large codebases with extensive source maps.
- **Background Processing**: Source map generation is performed asynchronously in a background thread,
  allowing the main bundling process to continue without blocking. This parallel processing can significantly
  reduce overall build times when working with JavaScript transform hooks.
- **Better Integration**: Seamless integration with rolldown's native Rust architecture.

chunkOptimization.description:
Control whether to optimize chunks by allowing entry chunks to have different exports than the underlying entry module. This optimization can reduce the number of generated chunks.

When enabled, rolldown will try to insert common modules directly into existing chunks rather than creating separate chunks for them, which can result in fewer output files and better performance.

This optimization is automatically disabled when any module uses top-level await (TLA) or contains TLA dependencies, as it could affect execution order guarantees.
chunkOptimization.markdownDescription:
Control whether to optimize chunks by allowing entry chunks to have different exports than the underlying entry module.
This optimization can reduce the number of generated chunks.

When enabled, rolldown will try to insert common modules directly into existing chunks rather than creating
separate chunks for them, which can result in fewer output files and better performance.

This optimization is automatically disabled when any module uses top-level await (TLA) or contains TLA dependencies,
as it could affect execution order guarantees.

experimental.description: Experimental features that may change in future releases and can introduce behavior change without a major version bump.
experimental.markdownDescription: Experimental features that may change in future releases and can introduce behavior change without a major version bump.

setPublicClassFields.description:
When using public class fields, assume that they don't shadow any getter in the current class, in its subclasses or in its superclass. Thus, it's safe to assign them rather than using `Object.defineProperty`.

For example:

Input: ```js class Test {  field = 2;

 static staticField = 3; } ```

When `set_public_class_fields` is `true`, the output will be: ```js class Test {  constructor() {    this.field = 2;  } } Test.staticField = 3; ```

Otherwise, the output will be: ```js import _defineProperty from "@oxc-project/runtime/helpers/defineProperty"; class Test {   constructor() {     _defineProperty(this, "field", 2);   } } _defineProperty(Test, "staticField", 3); ```

NOTE: For TypeScript, if you wanted behavior is equivalent to `useDefineForClassFields: false`, you should set both `set_public_class_fields` and [`crate::TypeScriptOptions::remove_class_fields_without_initializer`] to `true`.

assumptions.description: Set assumptions in order to produce smaller output.
assumptions.markdownDescription: Set assumptions in order to produce smaller output.

allowDeclareFields.description: When enabled, type-only class fields are only removed if they are prefixed with the declare modifier:
allowDeclareFields.markdownDescription: When enabled, type-only class fields are only removed if they are prefixed with the declare modifier:
allowDeclareFields.deprecated:
Allowing `declare` fields is built-in support in Oxc without any option. If you want to remove class fields
without initializer, you can use `remove_class_fields_without_initializer: true` instead.

removeClassFieldsWithoutInitializer.description:
When enabled, class fields without initializers are removed.

For example: ```ts class Foo {    x: number;    y: number = 0; } ``` // transform into ```js class Foo {    x: number; } ```

The option is used to align with the behavior of TypeScript's `useDefineForClassFields: false` option. When you want to enable this, you also need to set [`crate::CompilerAssumptions::set_public_class_fields`] to `true`. The `set_public_class_fields: true` + `remove_class_fields_without_initializer: true` is equivalent to `useDefineForClassFields: false` in TypeScript.

When `set_public_class_fields` is true and class-properties plugin is enabled, the above example transforms into:

```js class Foo {   constructor() {     this.y = 0;   } } ```

Defaults to `false`.

stripInternal.markdownDescription: Do not emit declarations for code that has an

declaration.description:
Also generate a `.d.ts` declaration file for TypeScript files.

The source file must be compliant with all [`isolatedDeclarations`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/release-notes/typescript-5-5.html#isolated-declarations) requirements.

Also generate a `.d.ts` declaration file for TypeScript files.

The source file must be compliant with all
[`isolatedDeclarations`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/release-notes/typescript-5-5.html#isolated-declarations)

rewriteImportExtensions.description:
Rewrite or remove TypeScript import/export declaration extensions.

- When set to `rewrite`, it will change `.ts`, `.mts`, `.cts` extensions to `.js`, `.mjs`, `.cjs` respectively.
- When set to `remove`, it will remove `.ts`/`.mts`/`.cts`/`.tsx` extension entirely.
- When set to `true`, it's equivalent to `rewrite`.
- When set to `false` or omitted, no changes will be made to the extensions.
rewriteImportExtensions.markdownDescription:
Rewrite or remove TypeScript import/export declaration extensions.

- When set to `rewrite`, it will change `.ts`, `.mts`, `.cts` extensions to `.js`, `.mjs`, `.cjs` respectively.
- When set to `remove`, it will remove `.ts`/`.mts`/`.cts`/`.tsx` extension entirely.
- When set to `true`, it's equivalent to `rewrite`.
- When set to `false` or omitted, no changes will be made to the extensions.

target.description:
Sets the target environment for the generated JavaScript.

The lowest target is `es2015`.

Example:

* `'es2015'`
* `['es2020', 'chrome58', 'edge16', 'firefox57', 'node12', 'safari11']`

legacy.description:
Enables experimental support for decorators, which is a version of decorators that predates the TC39 standardization process.

Decorators are a language feature which hasnt yet been fully ratified into the JavaScript specification. This means that the implementation version in TypeScript may differ from the implementation in JavaScript when it it decided by TC39.

ssr.markdownDescription:

dropLabels.description:

Labeled statements are JavaScript statements prefixed with a label identifier. This option allows you to strip specific labeled statements from the output, which is useful for removing debug-only code in production builds.

anyOf.markdownDescription: Configure how TSX and JSX are transformed.

jsx.description:
Controls how JSX syntax is transformed.

- If set to `false`, an error will be thrown if JSX syntax is encountered.
- If set to `'react'`, JSX syntax will be transformed to classic runtime React code.
- If set to `'react-jsx'`, JSX syntax will be transformed to automatic runtime React code.
- If set to `'preserve'`, JSX syntax will be preserved as-is.
jsx.markdownDescription:
Controls how JSX syntax is transformed.

- If set to `false`, an error will be thrown if JSX syntax is encountered.
- If set to `'react'`, JSX syntax will be transformed to classic runtime React code.
- If set to `'react-jsx'`, JSX syntax will be transformed to automatic runtime React code.
- If set to `'preserve'`, JSX syntax will be preserved as-is.

transform.description: Configure how the code is transformed. This process happens after the `transform` hook.
transform.markdownDescription: Configure how the code is transformed. This process happens after the `transform` hook.

skipWrite.description: Whether to skip the `bundle.write()` step when a rebuild is triggered.
skipWrite.markdownDescription: Whether to skip the `bundle.write()` step when a rebuild is triggered.

buildDelay.description:
Configures how long Rolldown will wait for further changes until it triggers a rebuild in milliseconds.

Even if this value is set to 0, there's a small debounce timeout configured in the file system watcher. Setting this to a value greater than 0 will mean that Rolldown will only trigger a rebuild if there was no change for the configured number of milliseconds. If several configurations are watched, Rolldown will use the largest configured build delay.
buildDelay.markdownDescription:
Configures how long Rolldown will wait for further changes until it triggers
a rebuild in milliseconds.

Even if this value is set to 0, there's a small debounce timeout configured
in the file system watcher. Setting this to a value greater than 0 will mean
that Rolldown will only trigger a rebuild if there was no change for the
configured number of milliseconds. If several configurations are watched,
Rolldown will use the largest configured build delay.

pollInterval.description:
Interval between each re-scan attempt in milliseconds.

This option is only used when polling backend is used.
pollInterval.markdownDescription:
Interval between each re-scan attempt in milliseconds.

This option is only used when polling backend is used.

compareContents.description:
Whether to compare file contents when checking for changes.

This is especially important for pseudo filesystems like those on Linux under `/sys` and `/proc` which are not obligated to respect any other filesystem norms such as modification timestamps, file sizes, etc. By enabling this feature, performance will be significantly impacted as all files will need to be read and hashed at each interval.

This option is only used when polling backend is used.
compareContents.markdownDescription:
Whether to compare file contents when checking for changes.

This is especially important for pseudo filesystems like those on Linux
under `/sys` and `/proc` which are not obligated to respect any other
filesystem norms such as modification timestamps, file sizes, etc. By
enabling this feature, performance will be significantly impacted as
all files will need to be read and hashed at each interval.

This option is only used when polling backend is used.

See [`output.cleanDir`](https://rolldown.rs/reference/OutputOptions.cleanDir).

Whether to emit warnings when Rolldown could not clean the output directory

pluginTimings.markdownDescription:

checks.description: Controls which warnings are emitted during the build process. Each option can be set to `true` (emit warning) or `false` (suppress warning).
checks.markdownDescription: Controls which warnings are emitted during the build process. Each option can be set to `true` (emit warning) or `false` (suppress warning).

preserveEntrySignatures.description:
Controls how entry chunk exports are preserved.

This determines whether Rolldown needs to create facade chunks (additional wrapper chunks) to maintain the exact export signatures of entry modules, or whether it can combine entry modules with other chunks for optimization.
preserveEntrySignatures.markdownDescription:
Controls how entry chunk exports are preserved.

This determines whether Rolldown needs to create facade chunks (additional wrapper chunks) to maintain the exact export signatures of entry modules, or whether it can combine entry modules with other chunks for optimization.

inlineConst.description:
Inline imported constant values during bundling instead of preserving variable references.

When enabled, constant values from imported modules will be inlined at their usage sites, potentially reducing bundle size and improving runtime performance by eliminating variable lookups.

**Options:**
- `true`: equivalent to `{ mode: 'all', pass: 1 }`, enabling constant inlining for all eligible constants with a single pass.
- `false`: Disable constant inlining
- `{ mode: 'smart' | 'all', pass?: number }`:   - `mode: 'smart'`: Only inline constants in specific scenarios where it is likely to reduce bundle size and improve performance.     Smart mode inlines constants in these specific scenarios:     1. `if (test) {} else {}` - condition expressions in if statements     2. `test ? a : b` - condition expressions in ternary operators     3. `test1 || test2` - logical OR expressions     4. `test1 && test2` - logical AND expressions     5. `test1 ?? test2` - nullish coalescing expressions  - `mode: 'all'`: Inline all imported constants wherever they are used.  - `pass`: Number of passes to perform for inlining constants.
inlineConst.markdownDescription:
Inline imported constant values during bundling instead of preserving variable references.

When enabled, constant values from imported modules will be inlined at their usage sites,
potentially reducing bundle size and improving runtime performance by eliminating variable lookups.

**Options:**
- `true`: equivalent to `{ mode: 'all', pass: 1 }`, enabling constant inlining for all eligible constants with a single pass.
- `false`: Disable constant inlining
- `{ mode: 'smart' | 'all', pass?: number }`:
  - `mode: 'smart'`: Only inline constants in specific scenarios where it is likely to reduce bundle size and improve performance.
    Smart mode inlines constants in these specific scenarios:
    1. `if (test) {} else {}` - condition expressions in if statements
    2. `test ? a : b` - condition expressions in ternary operators
    3. `test1 || test2` - logical OR expressions
    4. `test1 && test2` - logical AND expressions
    5. `test1 ?? test2` - nullish coalescing expressions
 - `mode: 'all'`: Inline all imported constants wherever they are used.
 - `pass`: Number of passes to perform for inlining constants.

build.description:
Build mode for the TypeScript compiler:

- If `true`, the plugin will use [`tsc -b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript) to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts` files.
- If `false`, the plugin will use [`tsc`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html) to emit `.d.ts` files without building referenced projects.
build.markdownDescription:
Build mode for the TypeScript compiler:

- If `true`, the plugin will use [`tsc -b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript) to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts` files.
- If `false`, the plugin will use [`tsc`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html) to emit `.d.ts` files without building referenced projects.

incremental.description:
If your tsconfig.json has [`references`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#references) option, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will use [`tsc
-b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript) to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts` files.

In such case, if this option is `true`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write down all built files into your disk, including [`.tsbuildinfo`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile) and other built files. This is equivalent to running `tsc -b` in your project.

Otherwise, if this option is `false`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write built files only into memory and leave a small footprint in your disk.

Enabling this option will decrease the build time by caching previous build results. This is helpful when you have a large project with multiple referenced projects.

By default, `incremental` is `true` if your tsconfig has [`incremental`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#incremental) or [`tsBuildInfoFile`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile) enabled.

This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is `false`.
incremental.markdownDescription:
If your tsconfig.json has
[`references`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#references) option,
`rolldown-plugin-dts` will use [`tsc
-b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript)
to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts`
files.

In such case, if this option is `true`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write
down all built files into your disk, including
[`.tsbuildinfo`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile)
and other built files. This is equivalent to running `tsc -b` in your
project.

Otherwise, if this option is `false`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write
built files only into memory and leave a small footprint in your disk.

Enabling this option will decrease the build time by caching previous build
results. This is helpful when you have a large project with multiple
referenced projects.

By default, `incremental` is `true` if your tsconfig has
[`incremental`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#incremental) or
[`tsBuildInfoFile`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile)
enabled.

This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is
`false`.

vue.description: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `vue-tsc`.
vue.markdownDescription: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `vue-tsc`.

tsMacro.description: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `@ts-macro/tsc`.
tsMacro.markdownDescription: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `@ts-macro/tsc`.

parallel.description: If `true`, the plugin will launch a separate process for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`. This enables processing multiple projects in parallel.
parallel.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will launch a separate process for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.
This enables processing multiple projects in parallel.

eager.description:
If `true`, the plugin will prepare all files listed in `tsconfig.json` for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.

This is especially useful when you have a single `tsconfig.json` for multiple projects in a monorepo.
eager.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will prepare all files listed in `tsconfig.json` for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.

This is especially useful when you have a single `tsconfig.json` for multiple projects in a monorepo.

newContext.description:
If `true`, the plugin will create a new isolated context for each build, ensuring that previously generated `.d.ts` code and caches are not reused.

By default, the plugin may reuse internal caches or incremental build artifacts to speed up repeated builds. Enabling this option forces a clean context, guaranteeing that all type definitions are generated from scratch.
newContext.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will create a new isolated context for each build,
ensuring that previously generated `.d.ts` code and caches are not reused.

By default, the plugin may reuse internal caches or incremental build artifacts
to speed up repeated builds. Enabling this option forces a clean context,
guaranteeing that all type definitions are generated from scratch.

emitJs.description:
If `true`, the plugin will emit `.d.ts` files for `.js` files as well. This is useful when you want to generate type definitions for JavaScript files with JSDoc comments.

Enabled by default when `allowJs` in compilerOptions is `true`. This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is `false`.
emitJs.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will emit `.d.ts` files for `.js` files as well.
This is useful when you want to generate type definitions for JavaScript files with JSDoc comments.

Enabled by default when `allowJs` in compilerOptions is `true`.
This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is
`false`.

cwd.description: The directory in which the plugin will search for the `tsconfig.json` file.
cwd.markdownDescription: The directory in which the plugin will search for the `tsconfig.json` file.

dtsInput.description:
Set to `true` if your entry files are `.d.ts` files instead of `.ts` files.

When enabled, the plugin will skip generating a `.d.ts` file for the entry point.
dtsInput.markdownDescription:
Set to `true` if your entry files are `.d.ts` files instead of `.ts` files.

emitDtsOnly.description:
If `true`, the plugin will emit only `.d.ts` files and remove all other output chunks.

This is especially useful when generating `.d.ts` files for the CommonJS format as part of a separate build step.
emitDtsOnly.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will emit only `.d.ts` files and remove all other output chunks.

The path to the `tsconfig.json` file.

If set to `false`, the plugin will ignore any `tsconfig.json` file. You can still specify `compilerOptions` directly in the options.

watchOptions.markdownDescription: Instructs the TypeScript compiler how to watch files.

typeAcquisition.description: Auto type (.d.ts) acquisition options for this project.
typeAcquisition.markdownDescription: Auto type (.d.ts) acquisition options for this project.

extends.description: Path to base configuration file to inherit from.
extends.markdownDescription: Path to base configuration file to inherit from.

files.description: If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`. When a `files` property is specified, only those files and those specified by `include` are included.
files.markdownDescription: If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`. When a `files` property is specified, only those files and those specified by `include` are included.

exclude.description:
Specifies a list of files to be excluded from compilation. The `exclude` property only affects the files included via the `include` property and not the `files` property.

Glob patterns require TypeScript version 2.0 or later.
exclude.markdownDescription:
Specifies a list of files to be excluded from compilation. The `exclude` property only affects the files included via the `include` property and not the `files` property.

Glob patterns require TypeScript version 2.0 or later.

include.description:
Specifies a list of glob patterns that match files to be included in compilation.

If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`.
include.markdownDescription:
Specifies a list of glob patterns that match files to be included in compilation.

If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`.

tsconfigRaw.description: Pass a raw `tsconfig.json` object directly to the plugin.
tsconfigRaw.markdownDescription: Pass a raw `tsconfig.json` object directly to the plugin.

sourcemap.description: If `true`, the plugin will generate declaration maps (`.d.ts.map`) for `.d.ts` files.
sourcemap.markdownDescription: If `true`, the plugin will generate declaration maps (`.d.ts.map`) for `.d.ts` files.

resolver.description:
Specifies a resolver to resolve type definitions, especially for `node_modules`.

- `'oxc'`: Uses Oxc's module resolution, which is faster and more efficient.
- `'tsc'`: Uses TypeScript's native module resolution, which may be more compatible with complex setups, but slower.
resolver.markdownDescription:
Specifies a resolver to resolve type definitions, especially for `node_modules`.

- `'oxc'`: Uses Oxc's module resolution, which is faster and more efficient.
- `'tsc'`: Uses TypeScript's native module resolution, which may be more compatible with complex setups, but slower.

cjsDefault.description:
Determines how the default export is emitted.

If set to `true`, and you are only exporting a single item using `export default ...`, the output will use `export = ...` instead of the standard ES module syntax. This is useful for compatibility with CommonJS.
cjsDefault.markdownDescription:
Determines how the default export is emitted.

If set to `true`, and you are only exporting a single item using `export default ...`,
the output will use `export = ...` instead of the standard ES module syntax.
This is useful for compatibility with CommonJS.

sideEffects.description:
Indicates whether the generated `.d.ts` files have side effects.
- If set to `true`, Rolldown will treat the `.d.ts` files as having side effects during tree-shaking.
- If set to `false`, Rolldown may consider the `.d.ts` files as side-effect-free, potentially removing them if they are not imported.
sideEffects.markdownDescription:
Indicates whether the generated `.d.ts` files have side effects.

- If set to `false`, Rolldown may consider the `.d.ts` files as side-effect-free, potentially removing them if they are not imported.

oxc.description:
If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using Oxc, which is significantly faster than the TypeScript compiler.

This option is automatically enabled when `isolatedDeclarations` in `compilerOptions` is set to `true`.

tsgo.description:
**[Experimental]** Enables DTS generation using `tsgo`.

To use this option, make sure `@typescript/native-preview` is installed as a dependency.

**Note:** This option is not yet recommended for production environments. `tsconfigRaw` and `isolatedDeclarations` options will be ignored when this option is enabled.

build.description:
Build mode for the TypeScript compiler:

- If `true`, the plugin will use [`tsc -b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript) to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts` files.
- If `false`, the plugin will use [`tsc`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html) to emit `.d.ts` files without building referenced projects.
build.markdownDescription:
Build mode for the TypeScript compiler:

- If `true`, the plugin will use [`tsc -b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript) to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts` files.
- If `false`, the plugin will use [`tsc`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html) to emit `.d.ts` files without building referenced projects.

incremental.description:
If your tsconfig.json has [`references`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#references) option, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will use [`tsc
-b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript) to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts` files.

In such case, if this option is `true`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write down all built files into your disk, including [`.tsbuildinfo`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile) and other built files. This is equivalent to running `tsc -b` in your project.

Otherwise, if this option is `false`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write built files only into memory and leave a small footprint in your disk.

Enabling this option will decrease the build time by caching previous build results. This is helpful when you have a large project with multiple referenced projects.

By default, `incremental` is `true` if your tsconfig has [`incremental`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#incremental) or [`tsBuildInfoFile`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile) enabled.

This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is `false`.

to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts`
files.

In such case, if this option is `true`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write

and other built files. This is equivalent to running `tsc -b` in your

referenced projects.

By default, `incremental` is `true` if your tsconfig has
[`incremental`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#incremental) or
[`tsBuildInfoFile`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile)
enabled.

This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is
`false`.

parallel.description: If `true`, the plugin will launch a separate process for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`. This enables processing multiple projects in parallel.

eager.description:
If `true`, the plugin will prepare all files listed in `tsconfig.json` for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.

This is especially useful when you have a single `tsconfig.json` for multiple projects in a monorepo.
eager.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will prepare all files listed in `tsconfig.json` for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.

This is especially useful when you have a single `tsconfig.json` for multiple projects in a monorepo.

newContext.description:
If `true`, the plugin will create a new isolated context for each build, ensuring that previously generated `.d.ts` code and caches are not reused.

By default, the plugin may reuse internal caches or incremental build artifacts to speed up repeated builds. Enabling this option forces a clean context, guaranteeing that all type definitions are generated from scratch.

exclude.description:

exclude.markdownDescription:

include.description:

- If `true`, the plugin will use [`tsc -b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript) to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts` files.
- If `false`, the plugin will use [`tsc`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html) to emit `.d.ts` files without building referenced projects.
build.markdownDescription:
Build mode for the TypeScript compiler:

- If `true`, the plugin will use [`tsc -b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript) to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts` files.
- If `false`, the plugin will use [`tsc`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html) to emit `.d.ts` files without building referenced projects.

incremental.description:
If your tsconfig.json has [`references`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#references) option, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will use [`tsc
-b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript) to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts` files.

In such case, if this option is `true`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write down all built files into your disk, including [`.tsbuildinfo`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile) and other built files. This is equivalent to running `tsc -b` in your project.

Otherwise, if this option is `false`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write built files only into memory and leave a small footprint in your disk.

Enabling this option will decrease the build time by caching previous build results. This is helpful when you have a large project with multiple referenced projects.

By default, `incremental` is `true` if your tsconfig has [`incremental`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#incremental) or [`tsBuildInfoFile`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile) enabled.

This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is `false`.
incremental.markdownDescription:
If your tsconfig.json has
[`references`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#references) option,
`rolldown-plugin-dts` will use [`tsc
-b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript)
to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts`
files.

In such case, if this option is `true`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write
down all built files into your disk, including
[`.tsbuildinfo`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile)
and other built files. This is equivalent to running `tsc -b` in your
project.

Otherwise, if this option is `false`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write
built files only into memory and leave a small footprint in your disk.

Enabling this option will decrease the build time by caching previous build
results. This is helpful when you have a large project with multiple
referenced projects.

By default, `incremental` is `true` if your tsconfig has
[`incremental`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#incremental) or
[`tsBuildInfoFile`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile)
enabled.

This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is
`false`.

vue.description: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `vue-tsc`.
vue.markdownDescription: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `vue-tsc`.

tsMacro.description: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `@ts-macro/tsc`.
tsMacro.markdownDescription: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `@ts-macro/tsc`.

parallel.description: If `true`, the plugin will launch a separate process for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`. This enables processing multiple projects in parallel.
parallel.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will launch a separate process for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.
This enables processing multiple projects in parallel.

eager.description:
If `true`, the plugin will prepare all files listed in `tsconfig.json` for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.

This is especially useful when you have a single `tsconfig.json` for multiple projects in a monorepo.
eager.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will prepare all files listed in `tsconfig.json` for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.

This is especially useful when you have a single `tsconfig.json` for multiple projects in a monorepo.

newContext.description:
If `true`, the plugin will create a new isolated context for each build, ensuring that previously generated `.d.ts` code and caches are not reused.

By default, the plugin may reuse internal caches or incremental build artifacts to speed up repeated builds. Enabling this option forces a clean context, guaranteeing that all type definitions are generated from scratch.
newContext.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will create a new isolated context for each build,
ensuring that previously generated `.d.ts` code and caches are not reused.

By default, the plugin may reuse internal caches or incremental build artifacts
to speed up repeated builds. Enabling this option forces a clean context,
guaranteeing that all type definitions are generated from scratch.

emitJs.description:
If `true`, the plugin will emit `.d.ts` files for `.js` files as well. This is useful when you want to generate type definitions for JavaScript files with JSDoc comments.

Enabled by default when `allowJs` in compilerOptions is `true`. This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is `false`.
emitJs.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will emit `.d.ts` files for `.js` files as well.
This is useful when you want to generate type definitions for JavaScript files with JSDoc comments.

Enabled by default when `allowJs` in compilerOptions is `true`.
This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is
`false`.

cwd.description: The directory in which the plugin will search for the `tsconfig.json` file.
cwd.markdownDescription: The directory in which the plugin will search for the `tsconfig.json` file.

dtsInput.description:
Set to `true` if your entry files are `.d.ts` files instead of `.ts` files.

When enabled, the plugin will skip generating a `.d.ts` file for the entry point.
dtsInput.markdownDescription:
Set to `true` if your entry files are `.d.ts` files instead of `.ts` files.

When enabled, the plugin will skip generating a `.d.ts` file for the entry point.

emitDtsOnly.description:
If `true`, the plugin will emit only `.d.ts` files and remove all other output chunks.

This is especially useful when generating `.d.ts` files for the CommonJS format as part of a separate build step.
emitDtsOnly.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will emit only `.d.ts` files and remove all other output chunks.

This is especially useful when generating `.d.ts` files for the CommonJS format as part of a separate build step.

tsconfig.description:
The path to the `tsconfig.json` file.

If set to `false`, the plugin will ignore any `tsconfig.json` file. You can still specify `compilerOptions` directly in the options.
tsconfig.markdownDescription:
The path to the `tsconfig.json` file.

If set to `false`, the plugin will ignore any `tsconfig.json` file.
You can still specify `compilerOptions` directly in the options.

watchOptions.description: Instructs the TypeScript compiler how to watch files.
watchOptions.markdownDescription: Instructs the TypeScript compiler how to watch files.

typeAcquisition.description: Auto type (.d.ts) acquisition options for this project.
typeAcquisition.markdownDescription: Auto type (.d.ts) acquisition options for this project.

extends.description: Path to base configuration file to inherit from.
extends.markdownDescription: Path to base configuration file to inherit from.

files.description: If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`. When a `files` property is specified, only those files and those specified by `include` are included.
files.markdownDescription: If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`. When a `files` property is specified, only those files and those specified by `include` are included.

exclude.description:
Specifies a list of files to be excluded from compilation. The `exclude` property only affects the files included via the `include` property and not the `files` property.

Glob patterns require TypeScript version 2.0 or later.
exclude.markdownDescription:
Specifies a list of files to be excluded from compilation. The `exclude` property only affects the files included via the `include` property and not the `files` property.

Glob patterns require TypeScript version 2.0 or later.

include.description:
Specifies a list of glob patterns that match files to be included in compilation.

If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`.
include.markdownDescription:
Specifies a list of glob patterns that match files to be included in compilation.

If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`.

tsconfigRaw.description: Pass a raw `tsconfig.json` object directly to the plugin.
tsconfigRaw.markdownDescription: Pass a raw `tsconfig.json` object directly to the plugin.

sourcemap.description: If `true`, the plugin will generate declaration maps (`.d.ts.map`) for `.d.ts` files.
sourcemap.markdownDescription: If `true`, the plugin will generate declaration maps (`.d.ts.map`) for `.d.ts` files.

resolver.description:
Specifies a resolver to resolve type definitions, especially for `node_modules`.

- `'oxc'`: Uses Oxc's module resolution, which is faster and more efficient.
- `'tsc'`: Uses TypeScript's native module resolution, which may be more compatible with complex setups, but slower.
resolver.markdownDescription:
Specifies a resolver to resolve type definitions, especially for `node_modules`.

- `'oxc'`: Uses Oxc's module resolution, which is faster and more efficient.
- `'tsc'`: Uses TypeScript's native module resolution, which may be more compatible with complex setups, but slower.

cjsDefault.description:
Determines how the default export is emitted.

If set to `true`, and you are only exporting a single item using `export default ...`, the output will use `export = ...` instead of the standard ES module syntax. This is useful for compatibility with CommonJS.
cjsDefault.markdownDescription:
Determines how the default export is emitted.

If set to `true`, and you are only exporting a single item using `export default ...`,
the output will use `export = ...` instead of the standard ES module syntax.
This is useful for compatibility with CommonJS.

sideEffects.description:
Indicates whether the generated `.d.ts` files have side effects.
- If set to `true`, Rolldown will treat the `.d.ts` files as having side effects during tree-shaking.
- If set to `false`, Rolldown may consider the `.d.ts` files as side-effect-free, potentially removing them if they are not imported.
sideEffects.markdownDescription:
Indicates whether the generated `.d.ts` files have side effects.
- If set to `true`, Rolldown will treat the `.d.ts` files as having side effects during tree-shaking.
- If set to `false`, Rolldown may consider the `.d.ts` files as side-effect-free, potentially removing them if they are not imported.

stripInternal.markdownDescription: Do not emit declarations for code that has an

oxc.description:
If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using Oxc, which is significantly faster than the TypeScript compiler.

This option is automatically enabled when `isolatedDeclarations` in `compilerOptions` is set to `true`.
oxc.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using Oxc,
which is significantly faster than the TypeScript compiler.

This option is automatically enabled when `isolatedDeclarations` in `compilerOptions` is set to `true`.

tsgo.description:
**[Experimental]** Enables DTS generation using `tsgo`.

To use this option, make sure `@typescript/native-preview` is installed as a dependency.

**Note:** This option is not yet recommended for production environments. `tsconfigRaw` and `isolatedDeclarations` options will be ignored when this option is enabled.
tsgo.markdownDescription:
**[Experimental]** Enables DTS generation using `tsgo`.

To use this option, make sure `@typescript/native-preview` is installed as a dependency.

**Note:** This option is not yet recommended for production environments.
`tsconfigRaw` and `isolatedDeclarations` options will be ignored when this option is enabled.

exclude.markdownDescription: Array, or not yet

splitting.description: Enable/disable CSS code splitting. When set to `false`, all CSS in the entire project will be extracted into a single CSS file. When set to `true`, CSS imported in async JS chunks will be preserved as chunks.
splitting.markdownDescription:
Enable/disable CSS code splitting.
When set to `false`, all CSS in the entire project will be extracted into a single CSS file.
When set to `true`, CSS imported in async JS chunks will be preserved as chunks.

-b`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html#build-mode-for-typescript)
to build the project and all referenced projects before emitting `.d.ts`
files.

In such case, if this option is `true`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write
down all built files into your disk, including
[`.tsbuildinfo`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile)
and other built files. This is equivalent to running `tsc -b` in your
project.

Otherwise, if this option is `false`, `rolldown-plugin-dts` will write
built files only into memory and leave a small footprint in your disk.

Enabling this option will decrease the build time by caching previous build
results. This is helpful when you have a large project with multiple
referenced projects.

By default, `incremental` is `true` if your tsconfig has
[`incremental`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#incremental) or
[`tsBuildInfoFile`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#tsBuildInfoFile)
enabled.

This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is
`false`.

vue.description: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `vue-tsc`.
vue.markdownDescription: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `vue-tsc`.

tsMacro.description: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `@ts-macro/tsc`.
tsMacro.markdownDescription: If `true`, the plugin will generate `.d.ts` files using `@ts-macro/tsc`.

parallel.description: If `true`, the plugin will launch a separate process for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`. This enables processing multiple projects in parallel.
parallel.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will launch a separate process for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.
This enables processing multiple projects in parallel.

eager.description:
If `true`, the plugin will prepare all files listed in `tsconfig.json` for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.

This is especially useful when you have a single `tsconfig.json` for multiple projects in a monorepo.
eager.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will prepare all files listed in `tsconfig.json` for `tsc` or `vue-tsc`.

This is especially useful when you have a single `tsconfig.json` for multiple projects in a monorepo.

newContext.description:
If `true`, the plugin will create a new isolated context for each build, ensuring that previously generated `.d.ts` code and caches are not reused.

By default, the plugin may reuse internal caches or incremental build artifacts to speed up repeated builds. Enabling this option forces a clean context, guaranteeing that all type definitions are generated from scratch.
newContext.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will create a new isolated context for each build,
ensuring that previously generated `.d.ts` code and caches are not reused.

By default, the plugin may reuse internal caches or incremental build artifacts
to speed up repeated builds. Enabling this option forces a clean context,
guaranteeing that all type definitions are generated from scratch.

emitJs.description:
If `true`, the plugin will emit `.d.ts` files for `.js` files as well. This is useful when you want to generate type definitions for JavaScript files with JSDoc comments.

Enabled by default when `allowJs` in compilerOptions is `true`. This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is `false`.
emitJs.markdownDescription:
If `true`, the plugin will emit `.d.ts` files for `.js` files as well.
This is useful when you want to generate type definitions for JavaScript files with JSDoc comments.

Enabled by default when `allowJs` in compilerOptions is `true`.
This option is only used when  {@link  Options.oxc }  is
`false`.

cwd.description: The directory in which the plugin will search for the `tsconfig.json` file.
cwd.markdownDescription: The directory in which the plugin will search for the `tsconfig.json` file.

dtsInput.description:
Set to `true` if your entry files are `.d.ts` files instead of `.ts` files.

When enabled, the plugin will skip generating a `.d.ts` file for the entry point.
dtsInput.markdownDescription:

emitDtsOnly.description:

This is especially useful when generating `.d.ts` files for the CommonJS format as part of a separate build step.
emitDtsOnly.markdownDescription:

If set to `false`, the plugin will ignore any `tsconfig.json` file. You can still specify `compilerOptions` directly in the options.

files.description: If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`. When a `files` property is specified, only those files and those specified by `include` are included.

When a `files` property is specified, only those files and those specified by `include` are included.

exclude.description:
Specifies a list of files to be excluded from compilation. The `exclude` property only affects the files included via the `include` property and not the `files` property.

Glob patterns require TypeScript version 2.0 or later.
exclude.markdownDescription:
Specifies a list of files to be excluded from compilation. The `exclude` property only affects the files included via the `include` property and not the `files` property.

include.description:
Specifies a list of glob patterns that match files to be included in compilation.

If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`.
include.markdownDescription:
Specifies a list of glob patterns that match files to be included in compilation.

If no `files` or `include` property is present in a `tsconfig.json`, the compiler defaults to including all files in the containing directory and subdirectories except those specified by `exclude`.

resolver.description:
Specifies a resolver to resolve type definitions, especially for `node_modules`.

- `'oxc'`: Uses Oxc's module resolution, which is faster and more efficient.
- `'tsc'`: Uses TypeScript's native module resolution, which may be more compatible with complex setups, but slower.
resolver.markdownDescription:

- `'oxc'`: Uses Oxc's module resolution, which is faster and more efficient.
- `'tsc'`: Uses TypeScript's native module resolution, which may be more compatible with complex setups, but slower.

cjsDefault.description:
Determines how the default export is emitted.

If set to `true`, and you are only exporting a single item using `export default ...`, the output will use `export = ...` instead of the standard ES module syntax. This is useful for compatibility with CommonJS.
cjsDefault.markdownDescription:

sideEffects.description:
Indicates whether the generated `.d.ts` files have side effects.
- If set to `true`, Rolldown will treat the `.d.ts` files as having side effects during tree-shaking.
- If set to `false`, Rolldown may consider the `.d.ts` files as side-effect-free, potentially removing them if they are not imported.
sideEffects.markdownDescription:
Indicates whether the generated `.d.ts` files have side effects.
